questions.text: Based on the disease shown in the image, which of the following specimens would the filarial worms be absent? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saliva

 

The image depicts a condition known as lymphatic filariasis, which is characterized by severe swelling of the limbs, commonly referred to as elephantiasis. Lymphatic filariasis is caused by parasitic worms, mainly Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori.

 

Filarial worms are not found in saliva, making it an unsuitable specimen for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood: Filarial worms are typically detected in the peripheral blood. Microfilariae are usually found in the blood, especially at night (nocturnal periodicity), which is the best time to collect blood samples for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Urine: Though it is uncommon, microfilariae can sometimes be detected in urine in cases of chyluria, where lymphatic fluid leaks into the urinary tract.

 

Option D. Hydrocoele fluid: Filarial worms can be present in hydrocoele fluid, which is the fluid collected from a hydrocele, a common manifestation of lymphatic filariasis in men.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In lymphatic filariasis, filarial worms (microfilariae) are typically absent in saliva. Blood samples collected at night are the most common and effective specimens for diagnosing the presence of these parasites.

questions.text: A patient is taking Clindamycin for a long period of time presented with diarrhea. Which of the following is causative organism for this? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CI. Difficile

 

Clostridium difficile (CI. difficile) is a bacterium that can cause a range of symptoms, from mild diarrhea to severe colitis. It is the most common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, particularly following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics such as clindamycin.

 

When antibiotics like clindamycin are taken for a long period of time, they can disrupt the normal gut flora. This disruption allows C. difficile to overgrow and produce toxins. The toxins produced by C. difficile (toxin A and toxin B) damage the intestinal lining, causing inflammation, diarrhea, and potentially severe complications such as pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, which is characterized by flaccid paralysis due to the production of botulinum toxin. It is not associated with antibiotic-induced diarrhea.

 

Option B. Clostridium tetani: Causes tetanus, presenting with muscle spasms and rigidity due to tetanospasmin toxin. It is not related to antibiotic use or diarrhea.

 

Option D. Clostridium perfringens: Causes gas gangrene and food poisoning but is not typically associated with antibiotic-induced diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile is the primary cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, particularly with the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin. Prompt recognition and appropriate treatment are essential to prevent severe complications such as pseudomembranous colitis.

 

C. Difficile-Associated Diarrhea (CDAD):

 

  • CDAD is a significant concern in patients using antibiotics like clindamycin.
  • If not treated in a timely manner, CDAD can lead to pseudomembranous colitis.
  • The treatment of choice (DOC) for C. difficile infection is fidaxomicin.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is used for the purpose of disinfection, to create the plasma which of the following substance is used? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Plasma sterilization is done with hydrogen peroxide. The mechanism of action is a free radical injury with hydrogen peroxide. Plasma sterilization is commonly used for sterilizing medical instruments that are sensitive to heat and moisture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethylene oxide: Incorrect. Ethylene oxide is used for sterilizing equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, and dental instruments, but it is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Option B. Glutaraldehyde: Incorrect. Glutaraldehyde is used for high-level disinfection of medical equipment like cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, and plastic endotracheal tubes but is not involved in plasma sterilization.

 

Option C. Formaldehyde: Incorrect. Formaldehyde is used for fumigation of operating theaters, wards, and laboratories but is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plasma sterilization: Is done with hydrogen peroxide, which creates reactive species that effectively sterilize medical instruments through free radical injury.
  • Ethylene oxide - Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments etc.
  • Gluteraldehyde - Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, Plastic ETT, face masks etc.
  • Formaldehyde - Fumigation of operating theater's, wards and labs.

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis is which category of bioweapon? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A

 

In Bioterrorism, there is intentional and deliberate release of biological agents (bacteria, viruses, or their toxins) to cause mass illness or death of people, animals, or plants

 

Bioweapons, or biological agents, are classified into three categories (A, B, and C) based on their risk to national security and public health. Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium that causes anthrax, is classified as a Category A bioweapon.

 

Category A:

 

  • Highest Priority: These agents pose the greatest risk to national security and public health because they can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, result in high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.
  • Examples: The mnemonic "Play with small, fine, bad" can help remember the agents in this category.
    • P: Plague (Yersinia pestis)
    • V: Viral hemorrhagic fevers
    • Small: Smallpox (Variola major)
    • Fine: Filoviridae (Ebola, Marburg)
    • 2B: Botulinum toxin, Bunyaviruses
    • 2A: Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis), Arenaviruses
    • T: Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: These agents are the second highest priority and are moderately easy to disseminate. They result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates. Examples –

 

 

Option C. Category C: These agents are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates. Examples –

 

 

Option D. Category D: This option is not part of the standard classification for bioweapons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Bacillus anthracis is classified as a Category A bioweapon due to its high potential for causing significant public health impact through easy dissemination and high mortality rates.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods are appropriate for identifying different strains of the same species of Mycobacterium tuberculosis? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. RFLP (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism)
  2. Chromosomal mutation detection
  3. Spoligotyping
  4. Multiple interspaced repetitive unit typing (MIRU-VNTR)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, c & d

 

To identify different strains of the same species of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, several molecular methods are available:

 

a. RFLP (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism): This method uses insertion sequences polymorphism to detect different strains. By identifying variations in restriction fragment patterns, different strains of the same species can be differentiated.

 

c. Spoligotyping: This technique involves direct repeat region space detection. The genome contains multiple repeat regions, and by detecting variations in these regions, different strains can be identified.

 

d. MIRU-VNTR (Multiple interspaced repetitive unit - Variable Number of Tandem Repeats): This method identifies repetitive units at specific loci in the genome. Variations in the number of repetitive units help distinguish different strains of the same species.

 

These three methods (a, c and d) are appropriate for strain identification within the same species.

 

Other Option:

 

b. Chromosomal mutation detection: This method detects single point mutations at the chromosomal level. While useful for detecting antibiotic resistance patterns, single point mutations do not provide sufficient information to differentiate between different strains of the same species. Point mutations may lead to antibiotic resistance but don't indicate strain differences within the same species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molecular methods for M. tuberculosis strain identification include RFLP, spoligotyping, and MIRU-VNTR typing, but not single chromosomal mutation detection.

questions.text: A pus swab should be discarded in which of the following waste containers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow bag

 

Pus swabs are considered soiled or infected waste materials. As per biomedical waste management guidelines, any material that is soiled, infected, or contaminated with blood or body fluids should be discarded in yellow bags. The yellow bag is specifically designated for:

 

  • Soiled waste
  • Items contaminated with blood
  • Body fluid contaminated items
  • Laboratory waste
  • Microbiological waste
  • Other infected materials

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Red bag: Incorrect because red bags are specifically meant for plastic waste materials such as IV sets, syringes (without needles), catheters, and other plastic medical items.

 

Option C. Black bag: Incorrect because black bags are designated for non-infectious general waste from hospitals such as papers, packaging materials, cartons, and food waste. These materials pose no infection risk.

 

Option D. Blue bag: Incorrect because blue bags/containers are meant for broken or discarded glass items, including:

 

  • Broken glassware
  • Medicine vials
  • Ampoules
  • Other glass materials used in healthcare settings

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Yellow bags are designated for soiled and infected waste materials in biomedical waste management, including pus swabs and other contaminated materials.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

choices.text: Sporothrix schencki
Corynebacterium minutissimum
Nocardia brasiliensis

questions.text: On inoculation in the skin, all of the following organisms can lead to dermal, subcutaneous, and lymphatic involvement except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corynebacterium minutissimum

 

Corynebacterium minutissimum causes a localized infection of the stratum corneum called erythrasma and does not involve the dermal, subcutaneous, or lymphatic tissues.

 

Details of Erythrasma:

 

  • Pathogen: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Common Sites: Axillae, groin, and other intertriginous areas
  • Clinical Features: Presents as well-demarcated, reddish-brown patches that can be mistaken for fungal infections.
  • Predisposing Factors: More common in diabetics and elderly individuals.
  • Diagnosis: Can be confirmed with Wood's lamp examination (coral-red fluorescence) and gram staining.
  • Growth Characteristics: This lipophilic corynebacterium grows readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, characterized by nodular lymphangitis. The infection can spread via lymphatic channels leading to a linear chain of nodules.

 

Option C. Nocardia brasiliensis: Causes nocardiosis, which can involve skin, subcutaneous tissues, and lymphatics, leading to nodular lymphangitis and abscess formation.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes a cutaneous infection that can progress along lymphatic channels leading to nodular lymphangitis, commonly seen in fish tank granuloma.

 

Educational objective

 

Corynebacterium minutissimum, the causative agent of erythrasma, is limited to superficial skin infections and does not cause dermal, subcutaneous, or lymphatic involvement.

 

Nodular lymphangitis, the most common causes include:

 

  1. Sporothrix schenckii
  2. Nocardia brasiliensis
  3. Mycobacterium marinum
  4. Leishmania brasiliensis

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase contrast microscopy

 

Phase-contrast microscopy (PCM) is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations.

 

Contrast is improved by using the difference in thickness or refractive index of structures within and around the cell. Difference in intensity of light is created as rays pass through varied refractive indices and produces contrast thus making the structures within the cells and its surroundings clearly visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Option C. The electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image, unlike the optical microscope that uses visible light to magnify images.

 

Option D. Polarized microscopy is used to visualize the intracellular structures using differences in birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria by converting phase shifts into brightness changes.

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: Which bacterium is typically described as club-shaped? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the causative agent of diphtheria, is typically described as club-shaped. The very name "Corynebacterium" derives from the Greek word "coryne" meaning "club." These bacteria have a characteristic morphology showing swollen ends that give them a club-shaped appearance. They also display a distinctive arrangement described as "Chinese letter" or "cuneiform" formation, where bacterial cells tend to lie at acute angles to each other due to their snapping type of division.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococci - Pneumococci (Streptococcus pneumoniae) are described as "flame-shaped" or "lanceolate" diplococci, not club-shaped. They typically appear as pairs of cocci with pointed ends facing outward, resembling a flame or lance shape. They may be encapsulated and are Gram-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Gonococci - Gonococci (Neisseria gonorrhoeae) are described as "kidney-shaped" or "bean-shaped" diplococci with adjacent sides concave, not club-shaped. They are Gram-negative diplococci that typically appear in pairs with their flat or concave sides facing each other.

 

Option D. V. Cholera - Vibrio cholerae is described as "curved, comma-shaped" Gram-negative bacilli, not club-shaped. These bacteria are curved rods with a single polar flagellum that gives them their characteristic "darting" motility. They do not exhibit the club-shaped morphology seen with Corynebacterium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae displays a distinctive club-shaped morphology with swollen ends and forms characteristic arrangements described as "Chinese letter" or "cuneiform" patterns due to their unique snapping division, which is a key microscopic feature for identification.

choices.text: Abnormal Expression of MHC Class II Molecule

questions.text: Epstein-Barr virus induces autoimmunity through which of the following mechanisms? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Polyclonal B Cell Activation

 

Explanation:


Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is specifically known to induce autoimmunity through polyclonal B cell activation. This mechanism involves direct stimulation of multiple B cell clones without antigen specificity, leading to excessive antibody production including autoantibodies. EBV can bypass the normal antigen-specific activation pathway, stimulating many B cell clones simultaneously and resulting in hypergammaglobulinemia with potential self-reactive antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molecular Mimicry - This mechanism involves microorganisms sharing antigenic determinants with self-antigens, causing cross-reactive immune responses. While this is a legitimate mechanism of autoimmunity (examples include Shigella flexneri and HLA B27), it's not the primary mechanism by which EBV induces autoimmunity.

 

Option B. Release of Sequestered Antigen - This occurs when normally hidden self-antigens (like spermatozoa or ocular antigens) are released following tissue injury, triggering an immune response. EBV does not primarily operate through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Abnormal Expression of MHC Class II Molecule - While alterations in MHC expression can contribute to autoimmunity, this is not the characteristic mechanism by which EBV induces autoimmune responses.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBV contributes to autoimmunity primarily through polyclonal B cell activation, which results in excessive production of antibodies, including potentially self-reactive ones, independent of specific antigenic stimulation.

questions.text: Bile Esculin Agar is used for the identification of: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Enterococcus faecalis

 

Explanation:

 

Bile Esculin Agar is specifically used to differentiate between Enterococcus (group D) from other streptococci. This medium helps detect two important characteristics: the ability to grow in the presence of 40% bile and the ability to hydrolyze esculin to esculetin and glucose. When Enterococcus faecalis grows on this medium, the esculetin combines with ferric ions to produce a black complex (phenolic iron complex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes - This is a Group A Streptococcus that doesn't grow well in the presence of bile and doesn't hydrolyze esculin. It's typically identified using other methods such as beta-hemolysis on blood agar and sensitivity to bacitracin.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae - Pneumococci are identified using other methods, particularly optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests. They don't typically grow on bile-containing media.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus - This is actually another name for Streptococcus pneumoniae (the same organism as in option C), so this is incorrect for the same reasons as option C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bile Esculin Agar exploits the unique ability of Group D streptococci (Enterococci) to grow in the presence of bile and hydrolyze esculin, producing a distinctive black color that serves as a valuable diagnostic feature.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

 

Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it's high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Screening Tests for UTI:

 

Option B. Griess Nitrite test: This test detects nitrites in the urine, which are generally produced by nitrate-reducing bacteria such as Escherichia coli, a common cause of UTIs. It is a quick and effective screening tool.

 

Option C. Leukocyte esterase test: This test identifies the presence of leukocyte esterase, an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes). A positive result suggests inflammation or infection, common in UTIs.

 

Option D. Wet mount examination: This involves examining a sample of urine under a microscope to detect the presence of pus cells, bacteria, or other elements indicative of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

 

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

 

Quantitative Culture:

 

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in LATTICE FORMATION where the antigen-antibody interactions are equal, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. The point where the antigen and the antibody are in the same amount , best interaction takes place in this zone called as the zone of equivalence. 

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These are not typically responsible for the phenomenon described. Incomplete antibodies generally do not cause agglutination but can bind antigens.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This would not typically result in the observed test pattern and is more relevant in tests involving complement fixation.

 

Option D. Post-zone phenomenon: Occurs when there is an excess of antigen, not antibodies, leading to a lack of visible agglutination due to insufficient cross-linking by antibodies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

 

  • IgM assay cannot be used to confirm a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin in stool samples.
  • C. difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus, causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection (CDI) after ingestion of spores of the organism.
  • The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). It is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin.
  • The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.
  • The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins - toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation.
  • The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.
  • Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin  A Or Toxin B or the organism in stool samples. The mere presence of bacteria in stool does not itend that the patient has the disease as clostridoides difficile is a commensal in the gut. Onlly confirmed toxin detection suggests significant infection with clostridoides difficile  This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 
  • Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment: This is true; fidaxomicin is a first-line treatment for C. difficile infection, especially in cases of recurrence.

 

Option B. It is toxin mediated: True; the clinical manifestations of CDI are due to the effects of toxins A and B.

 

Option D. Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris: Also true, this describes the characteristic appearance of the pseudomembrane seen in pseudomembranous colitis, a severe form of CDI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a genital ulcer, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Granuloma inguinale

 

The image shows a red, beefy genital ulcer. Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. This condition is characterized by painless, progressive ulcerative lesions without regional lymphadenopathy. The microscopic findings often reveal Donovan bodies, which are intracellular inclusions seen within macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphogranuloma venereum:

 

  • Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3).
  • It presents initially with a small, painless genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Characterized by painful genital ulcers and tender suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Gonorrhoea:

 

  • Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Typically presents with urethritis, cervicitis, and in some cases, disseminated infection. It does not usually present as an ulcerative genital lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady presented with foul smelling greyish white discharge and whiff test was positive. On examination following cells were seen as shown in image given below. Identify the causative organism and drug of choice? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gardnerella vaginalis, metronidazole

 

﻿﻿Amsel's criteria: Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed if any 3 of the following 4 findings are present

 

  1. Homogeneous white-gray vaginal discharge: Presence of a thin, milky discharge that adheres to the vaginal walls.
  2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5: Measurement of vaginal pH using pH paper or pH indicator strips, with a value above 4.5 indicating an elevated pH associated with BV.
  3. Positive "whiff test" or amine odor: Characteristic fishy odor when a sample of vaginal discharge is mixed with 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH).
  4. Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination: microscopic visualization of vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, which are called clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida, Fluconazole: Candida infections typically present with thick, white, "cottage cheese-like" discharge and intense itching. The cells would show budding yeast or pseudohyphae on microscopy, not clue cells.

 

Option B. Trichomonas, Metronidazole: Trichomonas vaginalis infection presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge and a strawberry cervix. The organism would appear as motile, flagellated protozoa on microscopy, not clue cells.

 

Option D. Gonococci, Doxycycline: Gonococcal infection (caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae) presents with purulent discharge and urethritis or cervicitis. Gram-negative intracellular diplococci would be seen on Gram stain, not clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the presence of clue cells, a positive whiff test, homogeneous discharge, and elevated vaginal pH. The causative organism is Gardnerella vaginalis, and the treatment of choice is metronidazole.

questions.text: A Patient is infected with a dimorphic fungus which involves the subcutaneous layers, identify the organism responsible for it? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix

 

The clinical presentation suggests an infection with a dimorphic fungus that primarily affects the subcutaneous layers.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus known for causing subcutaneous infections. It spreads via lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes and is commonly associated with "rose gardener's disease."

 

Key Points about Sporothrix schenckii:

 

  • Dimorphic Nature: Sporothrix schenckii can exist in both mold and yeast forms.
  • Subcutaneous Infection: Typically causes chronic skin infections and spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Common Name: Often referred to as "rose gardener's disease" due to its association with thorn pricks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Incorrect. Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus but typically causes pulmonary and disseminated infections, not primarily subcutaneous infections.

 

Option B. Chromoblastomycosis: Incorrect. Chromoblastomycosis is caused by several dematiaceous (darkly pigmented) fungi, such as Fonsecaea pedrosoi, and is not dimorphic.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, which is not a dimorphic fungus and typically causes polypoidal masses in mucous membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes subcutaneous infections, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease," and spreads via lymphatic channels.

 

Examples of dimorphic fungi - Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii

choices.text: Thin septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with dysphagia and odynophagia. Endoscopic examination of the esophagus reveals plaques. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae

 

An HIV-positive patient presenting with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and odynophagia (painful swallowing) along with esophageal plaques most likely has esophageal candidiasis. This is one of the most common opportunistic infections in HIV patients and typically presents as white plaques on the esophageal mucosa.

 

The characteristic microscopic appearance of Candida species includes budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. Candida has the ability to transform between three phenotypic forms: yeast (blastospores), pseudohyphae, and true hyphae. The budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae are the pathognomonic features seen on microscopic examination of esophageal candidiasis specimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thin septate hyphae with acute angle branching: This describes Aspergillus species, which typically cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients rather than esophageal plaques.

 

Option C. Acid fast bacilli: This describes mycobacteria, which can cause disseminated disease in HIV patients but do not typically present as esophageal plaques with dysphagia and odynophagia.

 

Option D. Squamous cell cancer: While malignancies can occur in HIV patients, the presentation with characteristic white plaques and the clinical scenario strongly suggest an infectious etiology rather than cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, characterized by white plaques and microscopic findings of budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae.

questions.text: Match each disease with the correct causative agent from the options provided: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

 

The correct matching is:

 

  • Donovanosis - Klebsiella granulomatis (A-2)
  • Oroya fever - Bartonella bacilliformis (B-3)
  • Rat bite fever - Streptobacillus moniliformis (C-4)
  • Pinta - Treponema carateum (D-1)

 

For each disease:

 

  1. Donovanosis is a sexually transmitted infection that causes ulcerative lesions, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  2. Oroya fever, also known as Carrion's disease, is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis and is transmitted by sandflies.
  3. Rat bite fever is an infection caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis, typically transmitted through rat bites or contact with rat excreta.
  4. Pinta is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema carateum, characterized by skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The specific causative organisms for these bacterial diseases:

 

  • Donovanosis → Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Oroya fever → Bartonella bacilliformis
  • Rat bite fever → Streptobacillus moniliformis
  • Pinta → Treponema carateum

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • The provided clinical scenario presents a patient with symptoms of anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an accompanying image displaying hydrops fetalis.
  • These manifestations collectively suggest a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as Fifth disease, which is caused by parvovirus B19.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

 

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

 

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

 

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) in pregnancy leads to subsequent pregnancy loss.

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) by trans placental spread causes fetal damage at all gestational ages. Features are periventricular calcifications, microcephaly, hearing loss, hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: On Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining oocysts of size 8-10 µm cysts are visible. Identify the organism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclospora

 

Cyclospora cayetanensis is a coccidian parasite that causes the gastrointestinal disease cyclosporiasis. The organism produces oocysts that are 8-10 µm in diameter, which can be detected by Ziehl-Neelsen staining. The oocysts exhibit a variable acid-fast staining property and can also autofluoresce under ultraviolet light.

 

Cyclospora oocysts have the following characteristics:

 

  • Size: 8-10 µm in diameter.
  • Staining: They show variable acid-fast staining.
  • Autofluorescence: They exhibit blue-green autofluorescence under ultraviolet light.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Isospora: Isospora (now known as Cystoisospora) produces larger oocysts, typically 20-30 µm in size, and contains two sporocysts with four sporozoites each. It does not match the 8-10 µm size described.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are smaller, measuring 4-6 µm in diameter, and consistently exhibit acid-fast staining and bright auramine fluorescence. They do not match the size range described.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are a group of spore-forming unicellular parasites that do not fit the description of having 8-10 µm oocysts visible with Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Malaria (A-4, Giemsa stain): Giemsa's solution is a mixture of methylene blue, eosin, and Azure B. It is used to stain blood smears for the identification of malarial parasites. Giemsa's stain is regarded as the world's standard diagnostic technique for malaria's plasmodium, and it is also the basic stain for classifying lymphomas in the Kiel classification.
  • Tuberculosis (B-1, ZN stain): The Ziehl-Neelsen method uses a carbol fuchsin stain, acid alcohol decolorizer, and methylene blue counterstain. Acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, stain red, while the background of debris stains blue. The ZN stain confirms the acid-fast property of mycobacteria.
  • Leprosy (C-2, Fite Faraco stain): Fite-Faraco stain is the routinely used method to demonstrate Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. It is more sensitive than the ZN method in the detection of Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. The leprosy bacillus is much less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus, therefore alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

Mycobacterial cell walls contain a waxy substance composed of mycolic acids. These are ß-hydroxy carboxylic acids with chain lengths of up to 90 carbon atoms. The property of acid fastness is related to the carbon chain length of the mycolic acid found in any particular species.

 

  • Actinomycosis (D-3, Gram stain): Actinomyces species are gram-positive bacteria, and the Gram stain is used to visualize them. Actinomyces appear as filamentous, branching, gram-positive rods when stained with the Gram stain. Gram stain is more sensitive for the diagnosis of actinomycosis than culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

The image depicts the life cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which involves various hosts and vectors. Here's the correct matching:

 

  1. Accidental host (Human) - c: Humans are considered accidental hosts for JEV as they do not contribute to the ongoing transmission cycle.
  2. Amplifier (Pigs) - d: Pigs serve as amplifier hosts where the virus replicates to high levels, increasing the likelihood of mosquito transmission.
  3. Reservoir (Ardeid bird) - a: Birds, particularly Ardeid birds (herons and egrets), act as natural reservoirs of JEV.
  4. Vector (Culex) - b: Culex mosquitoes are the primary vectors that transmit JEV from reservoir hosts to amplifier hosts and to accidental hosts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle:

 

  • Humans are accidental hosts.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts.
  • Ardeid birds are reservoir hosts.
  • Culex mosquitoes are the vectors responsible for transmission.

choices.text: Toxoplasma gondii

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The given image shows the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis.

 

Definitive hosts - Members of Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts.

 

Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents). Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

 

Life cycle of toxoplasma gondii

 

  1. Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cat’s feces. Although oocysts are usually only shed for 1–3 weeks, large numbers may be shed.
  2. Oocysts take 1–5 days to sporulate in the environment and become infective. Intermediate hosts in nature (including birds and rodents) become infected after ingesting soil, water or plant material contaminated with oocysts.
  3. Oocysts transform into tachyzoites shortly after ingestion. These tachyzoites localize in neural and muscle tissue and develop into tissue cyst bradyzoites.
  4. Cats become infected after consuming intermediate hosts harboring tissue cysts. Cats may also become infected directly by ingestion of sporulated oocysts.
  5. Animals bred for human consumption and wild game may also become infected with tissue cysts after ingestion of sporulated oocysts in the environment.

 

Humans can become infected by any of several routes:

 

  • Eating undercooked meat of animals harboring tissue cysts
  • Consuming food or water contaminated with cat feces or by contaminated environmental samples (such as fecal-contaminated soil or changing the litter box of a pet cat).
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation.
  • Transplacentally from mother to fetus.
  • In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes; these cysts may remain throughout the life of the host.

 

 

Diagnosis is usually achieved by serology, although tissue cysts may be observed in stained biopsy specimens.

 

Diagnosis of congenital infections can be achieved by detecting T. gondii DNA in amniotic fluid using molecular methods such as PCR

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cystoisospora: Causes isosporiasis, primarily affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Its lifecycle involves humans as the definitive host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Causes cryptosporidiosis, an intestinal illness. The lifecycle involves direct fecal-oral transmission.

 

Option C. Plasmodium knowlesi: Causes malaria, with a lifecycle involving mosquitoes as vectors and humans as host.

 

Educational Objective

 

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies

 

Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. It affects the central nervous system. It is a zoonotic disease, transmitted by a deep bite or scratch from an animal with rabies, which is, in 99% of the cases, a dog. It is preventable by a vaccine.

 

Nipah virus infection is fatal in 40 to 70 percent of cases.

 

Ebola case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus infection has a fatality rate of 40% to 70%. While severe, it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies once symptoms develop.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus disease has variable case fatality rates, ranging from 25% to 90% in different outbreaks. However, it is not as consistently fatal as rabies once symptoms manifest.

 

Option D. Zika: Zika virus infection is typically mild, and while it can cause severe complications such as microcephaly in newborns if contracted during pregnancy, it does not have a high mortality rate in symptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

choices.text: It is a single-stranded RNA virus.
The primary mode of transmission is through the respiratory route.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Parvovirus B-19: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. It is a single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Explanation:


Parvovirus B-19 is a single-stranded DNA virus, not an RNA virus. This is a fundamental characteristic of the virus. Parvoviridae family viruses are known for being the smallest DNA viruses, with B-19 containing single-stranded DNA within its non-enveloped, icosahedral structure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The primary mode of transmission is through the respiratory route - This statement is correct. Parvovirus B-19 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets, making respiratory transmission the main route of infection. It can also spread through fomites and vertical (mother-to-child) transmission.

 

Option C. It is a DNA virus - This statement is correct. Parvovirus B-19 is definitively a DNA virus, specifically containing single-stranded DNA. This is a key characteristic that distinguishes it from RNA viruses.

 

Option D. It affects erythroid progenitors - This statement is correct. Parvovirus B-19 has a specific tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. This tropism explains its clinical manifestations including severe anemia, transient aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis in fetuses.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Parvovirus B-19 is a single-stranded DNA virus that primarily infects erythroid progenitor cells, causing conditions like erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), transient aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis in fetuses.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent episodes of respiratory infections, primarily caused by bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules. Which immunoglobulin subclass deficiency is most likely to be responsible for these infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. IgG2

 

Explanation:


IgG2 antibody is specifically directed against polysaccharide antigens and is the most important defense against encapsulated bacteria. When a child has a deficiency in this particular IgG subclass, they become highly susceptible to recurrent infections with polysaccharide-encapsulated bacteria, which commonly cause respiratory infections. These include pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and other bacteria with prominent polysaccharide capsules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA - While IgA deficiency is the most common immunodeficiency and can lead to respiratory infections, it primarily affects mucosal immunity rather than specific defense against encapsulated bacteria. IgA deficiency typically manifests as increased susceptibility to sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea.

 

Option B. IgG1 - This is the most abundant IgG subclass (65% of total IgG) and responds primarily to protein antigens, not polysaccharide capsules. A deficiency would cause broad susceptibility to infections but not specifically to encapsulated bacteria.

 

Option D. IgG3 - This subclass typically responds to protein antigens rather than polysaccharides. IgG3 deficiency would not specifically predispose to infections with encapsulated bacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

IgG2 is the critical immunoglobulin subclass for defense against encapsulated bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules, making its deficiency the most likely cause of recurrent respiratory infections with these specific pathogens.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon gamma release assay

 

TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

 

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

 

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 

T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.

 

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TrueNat TB: Incorrect, as this molecular test diagnoses TB and tests for rifampicin resistance using a sputum sample, not whole blood.

 

Option B. Gene Xpert: Incorrect, this is another molecular test that identifies TB and resistance to rifampicin but also uses sputum samples rather than whole blood.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect, as only the interferon gamma release assay is designed to be used with whole blood samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon gamma release assay is a valuable tool for diagnosing latent TB, particularly suitable for patients who may not be effectively diagnosed through traditional skin tests, offering a sensitive and specific method that utilizes whole blood to detect an immune response to TB antigens.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.

 

To perform Kirby-Bauer's disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

 

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

 

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E-test (Epsilometer)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: This method involves incorporating different concentrations of antibiotics into agar plates. It's primarily a quantitative technique that provides the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of antibiotics.

 

Option C. Broth dilution method: Similar to the agar dilution method but performed in a liquid medium. This method also determines the MIC of antibiotics.

 

Option D. PCR based assay: This molecular method detects the presence of specific antibiotic resistance genes but does not directly test the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next best step of management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

 

Given patient with fever and filarial antigen test positive points to diagnosis of filariasis. And the next best step for this patient is the detection of microfilariae in the blood smear.

 

The gold standard method to diagnose active infection is by demonstrating microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopy.

 

It is critical and should be based on the periodicity of the microfilariae. For nocturnal periodicity, blood should be collected between 9 pm and 2 am.

 

DEC provocation test is done to collect the blood in the day time. Patient takes a tablet of DEC orally (2mg/kg) so that the nocturnal microfilariae are stimulated and come to peripheral blood within 30 minutes.

 

Although there is an advantage of blood sample collection even during day time, the guidelines from CDC, NVBDCP, and IAPSM suggest blood sample collection at night, followed by identification of microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopic examination as the standard method for diagnosis.

 

Other methods to detect adult worms include:

 

  • Lymph node biopsy to detect adult worms.
  • X-ray (if worms are calcified)
  • High-frequency ultrasound and doppler of the scrotum (Option D).
  • Serology - Antigen detection by using monoclonal antibodies against Og4C3 and AD12 antigens.
  • ELISA and ICT

 

Treatment - Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) → DOC. Given orally in a dose of 6 mg per kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days. It kills microfilariae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone Marrow Biopsy: Not relevant for filariasis, as it does not involve the bone marrow.

 

Option B. DEC Provocation Test: While useful for driving microfilariae into the peripheral blood for easier detection during daytime, it is less direct than a nighttime blood smear.

 

Option D. Ultrasound of the Scrotum: Useful in chronic cases to detect adult worms in lymphatic vessels, particularly in cases of lymphatic filariasis affecting the scrotum, but not as immediate or definitive for acute diagnosis as a blood smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For direct confirmation of active filarial infection, detection of microfilariae in a blood smear is essential. This method provides clear evidence of the parasites in the bloodstream, crucial for diagnosing and managing filariasis effectively.

questions.text: Gamma radiation is used for sterilization of: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Syringes, needles and catheters

 

Gamma radiation is used for the sterilization of articles such as syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves.

 

Gamma particles show maximum penetration and since there is no increase in temperature during the process it is called as cold sterilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contaminated clothes and animal carcasses: While gamma radiation can theoretically be used for these purposes, it is not typically employed due to practicality and cost. Incineration or chemical disinfection are more common methods for dealing with contaminated clothes and animal carcasses.

 

Option C. Gloves and aprons: Though gamma radiation can sterilize gloves and aprons, it is less common compared to other methods like ethylene oxide gas or steam sterilization, which are more cost-effective for these items.

 

Option D. Bacterial vaccines and intravenous solutions: Gamma radiation is generally not used for sterilizing vaccines and intravenous solutions because it can degrade the active components and alter their effectiveness. These are typically sterilized using filtration or other methods that preserve their integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma radiation is an effective sterilization method for medical devices like syringes, needles, and catheters due to its deep penetration and ability to destroy pathogens without raising temperatures.

questions.text: Reinfection with which of the following virus can lead to more severe disease with complications? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

Dengue virus infection can be caused by any of the four serotypes (DEN-1, DEN-2, DEN-3, DEN-4). A primary infection with one serotype usually results in immunity to that specific serotype. However, reinfection with a different serotype can lead to more severe disease due to a phenomenon known as antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). This process can cause a more severe form of the disease, such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) or Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS), especially with Dengue virus serotype 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Rabies is almost always fatal once clinical symptoms appear, but it does not exhibit increased severity upon reinfection as it is typically a once-in-a-lifetime infection.

 

Option C. Measles: Reinfection with measles is rare due to the strong, long-lasting immunity conferred by initial infection or vaccination. Complications are generally more severe during the initial infection.

 

Option D. Mumps: Reinfection with mumps is uncommon due to the immunity developed after the first infection or vaccination. Complications are not typically more severe upon reinfection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinfection with Dengue virus can lead to more severe disease due to antibody-dependent enhancement, especially with Dengue virus serotype 2, leading to conditions such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) and Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS).

 

Note -

 

﻿﻿Serotype: 1, 2, 3, 4

 

﻿﻿Most dangerous serotype: type 2

questions.text: A child who is regularly eating outside is presenting with icterus and diarrhea, which of the following infectious agent can spread through the Feco-oral route? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis A

 

Hepatitis A is a viral liver infection that spreads primarily through the feco-oral route, often through contaminated food and water. It is commonly associated with poor sanitation and overcrowded areas, making it prevalent in areas with inadequate food and water hygiene.

 

Key Points about Hepatitis A:

 

  • Transmission Route: Spread through the feco-oral route.
  • Symptoms: Can cause icterus (jaundice) and gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.
  • Risk Factors: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with the virus, especially in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Prevention: Good hygiene practices, proper sanitation, and vaccination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Incorrect. Hepatitis B is primarily spread through blood, sexual contact, and from mother to child during childbirth, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C: Incorrect. Hepatitis C is mainly transmitted through blood-to-blood contact, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D: Incorrect. Hepatitis D only occurs in those infected with Hepatitis B and is transmitted in the same ways as Hepatitis B, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E spread through the Feco-oral route

 

Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually

choices.text: Transmitted more in third trimester than first
Releases cysts in stool that are immediately infective
Can be grown in peritoneum of mice

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Toxoplasma gondii are true, except: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Releases cysts in stool that are immediately infective

 

The statement "Releases cysts in stool that are immediately infective" is FALSE. Toxoplasma gondii oocysts released in cat feces are NOT immediately infective. The oocysts must undergo sporulation in the soil environment before becoming infective. This sporulation process takes time and environmental conditions, making the oocysts non-infective immediately after excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted more in third trimester than first - This is true. Congenital toxoplasmosis transmission risk is higher in the third trimester compared to the first trimester. However, if infection occurs in the first trimester, it typically results in more severe congenital toxoplasma syndrome.
