Option C. Can be grown in peritoneum of mice - This is true. Toxoplasma gondii can be cultured in the peritoneum of mice, which is one of the laboratory methods used for research and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Infects most mammals and birds - This is true. Toxoplasma gondii has a broad host range and can infect most mammals and birds, which serve as intermediate hosts. Humans are also intermediate hosts in this life cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxoplasma gondii oocysts require sporulation in the environment before becoming infective; they are not immediately infective upon excretion.

choices.text: Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings
All pathogenic strains are urease positive

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cryptococcus, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD4 count greater than 500

 

Cryptococcus infection occurs when CD4 counts fall below 100 cells/microliter. This makes option d incorrect as Cryptococcus infections do not occur at CD4 counts greater than 500. The infection is strongly associated with severe immunocompromise, particularly in AIDS patients with very low CD4 counts (<100 cells/μL).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary cryptococcus is AIDS defining: Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis is considered an AIDS-defining illness. When Cryptococcus spreads beyond the lungs in HIV patients, it signifies advanced immunosuppression and meets criteria for AIDS diagnosis.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings: While Cryptococcus neoformans is the more commonly known species, Cryptococcus gatti is also associated with bird droppings, particularly pigeon excreta. Both species can be found in soil contaminated with bird droppings.

 

Option C. All pathogenic strains are urease positive: All pathogenic strains of Cryptococcus are urease positive. This is an important diagnostic feature used to identify Cryptococcus species in laboratory testing. The urease test helps differentiate Cryptococcus from other yeasts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cryptococcal infections occur at CD4 counts less than 100 cells/microliter, not at counts greater than 500. This is a crucial diagnostic criterion for suspecting cryptococcal infection in HIV/AIDS patients.

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: Vaccine can be prepared against which of the following proteins of the virus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

The L1 protein of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a major capsid protein and is the primary antigen used in the development of HPV vaccines. L1 proteins can self-assemble into virus-like particles (VLPs) which mimic the natural virus structure but do not contain viral DNA, making them non-infectious. These VLPs elicit a strong immune response, providing protection against HPV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6 and E7 proteins: These are oncogenes of HPV responsible for cellular transformation and promoting oncogenesis. These proteins drive cell cycle allowing genome amplification in upper epithelial layers and degrade tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and pRb. They are not used for vaccine preparation as they do not induce a protective immune response.

 

Option C. E1 and E2 proteins: These are involved in viral replication and transcription regulation. E1 acts as an origin binding protein and ATPase-dependent helicase, while E2 regulates viral gene transcription and is associated with E1 for viral genome partitioning. They are not targets for the current vaccines.

 

Option D. DE3: This option is not relevant to HPV proteins in the context of vaccine development.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia. Caused by Coxsackie A virus. The presence of vesicular rashes in these specific locations is a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In Dengue Fever, the initial rash is a transient flushing erythema of face that typically occurs shortly before or within the first 24-48 hours of the onset of symptoms and is thought to be the result of capillary dilatation. The second rash usually occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and it is characterized by asymptomatic maculopapular or morbilliform eruption.

 

Option C. The rash associated with the Zika virus is a combination of flat blotches (macules) and raised tiny reddish bumps like papules (not as petechiae)

 

Option D. In roseola infantum, upon rapid defervescence of the fever around days three to five, small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules will develop. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. The rash is typically nonpruritic, blanching and can persist from one to two days. Caused by HHV 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicular rash is specifically seen in Hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevotella

 

The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

 

Prevotella spp are anaerobic, gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.

 

Prevotella spp. are members of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota and are often recovered from anaerobic infections of the respiratory tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia cepacia:  Is gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Option B. Yersinia enterocolitica: Are gram negative facultative anaerobes.

 

Option C. Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: Are gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.
